full_text.20: @BrianRoemmele Blaming bitcoin for the actions of SBF and FTX is like blaming the dollar bill when a bank goes insolvent.
full_text.21: @realMeetKevin The value is largely supply and demand driven. It's buttressed by the control of supply (finite supply w bitcoin), control of demand (user trust, policy, etc), utility, and the cost of mining (a miner invests in equipment, time, and energy - they won't want to sell for a loss)
full_text.22: @steve_alarm @LukeGromen @LynAldenContact @Bumpygordon If you wouldn’t blame the dollars in a bank for the bank’s insolvency, you shouldn’t blame Bitcoin for FTX’s insolvency.

full_text.34: @dextrosensei @volcanotim @DylanLeClair_ Though of course the "Bitcoin exists" part is not a guarantee.
full_text.35:
@dextrosensei @volcanotim @DylanLeClair_ 3 outcomes:
1. Price will be higher than 200k, remain profitable
OR
2. Mining will be more efficient/less expensive, remain profitable
OR
3. Mining will become easier, remain profitable

There is no long-term scenario where Bitcoin exists and mining is not profitable.
full_text.36:
@dextrosensei @volcanotim @DylanLeClair_ Of course they can. This is how Bitcoin started. And if it were to ever become that worthless, nobody will bother to spend significant value to attack it. That's what Satoshi was getting at when he discussed incentives.

Unlikely for us to ever get back to that point ofc.
full_text.37: @volcanotim @dextrosensei @DylanLeClair_ Unless a real Doomsday scenario played out, there will always be a miner able to make a profit, regardless of those factors. If Bitcoin tanked and all the big players in the mining game exited, then you'd be able to mine again with your GPU. And eventually a laptop CPU.
full_text.38:
Great article! ...and pairs nicely with my friend @dmlayt's newest piece: 
https://t.co/wOEndeWPH8 https://t.co/nyJ1izxo6W
full_text.39: @dextrosensei @volcanotim @DylanLeClair_ Satoshi wrote about this in the WP. The incentive is always greater to support Bitcoin than it is to attack it. I believe an attacker would need to be motivated by something else (such as destroying it to protect status).
full_text.41: @dextrosensei @volcanotim @DylanLeClair_ Ah, I see what you're saying. Though I think it's a little more complex than that. Bitcoin is exponentially more secure than it was 5 years ago, it takes a lot of power to overturn all that collateral energy.
